meaning_mnemonic: In <radical>prison</radical>, <radical>Wolverine</radical> gets picked on for the <radical>barb</radical>s coming out of his hands. This creates a lot of <kanji>conflict</kanji> between him and the other prisoners. They don't take kindly to mutants, and Wolverine doesn't take kindly to bigots — hence the conflict.

A <radical>leader</radical> who takes the <radical>middle</radical> of the road on every issue is likely to have an average <kanji>relationship</kanji> with everyone. He doesn't really take sides in matters, and just stays in the middle. This makes him seem like a wishy-washy people-pleaser, and as such he's only able to maintain average, mid-tier relationships.

The <radical>leader</radical> has a <radical>cloud</radical> that he uses to <kanji>transmit</kanji> all of the messages he needs to send to his people. The cloud floats above him and when he wants to tell people something he just whispers into the cloud and it transmits his message really, really loudly to all of them.

The card game fish are best at is <radical>blackjack</radical> because they can easily hold the cards with their <radical>fins</radical> <kanji>together</kanji>. In blackjack you don't have to have a huge hand, full of cards. It's just a few, so fish fins can keep them together and just hit or stay.
There is a <radical>woman</radical> and a <radical>child</radical> in front of you. You <kanji>like</kanji> them very much.

When a <radical>drunkard</radical> holds a <radical>sword</radical> it <kanji>becomes</kanji> something else. The drunkard doesn't become a swordsman, they're still just a drunkard. But the sword in their hands does.

By the time you finish digging a <radical>coffin</radical> hole with nothing but a <radical>spoon</radical>, you’ll be an old <kanji>elderly</kanji> person. Digging with nothing but a spoon takes a long time, especially when the hole needs to be big enough for a coffin. You might as well be digging it for yourself at this rate. By the time you finish, you’ll be all wrinkled and elderly and just about ready to keel over.
A <radical>leader</radical> <radical>stand</radical>s at the highest <kanji>rank</kanji> in an organization. The leader is of the highest rank and stands above all others.

The <radical>leader</radical> of your <radical>clan</radical> wants to live close to the <radical>ground</radical> so he demands you get <kanji>low</kanji>. Low, low, with your belly to the ground. That way you're always below him, since he's the leader.

If you want a <radical>spirit</radical> <radical>sword</radical>, you have to be the <kanji>first</kanji> one to find it. Do you really think the first person to come across a spirit sword wouldn't want it?! No. So if you're any place but first, you're not getting anything.
In your <radical>mouth</radical> you put a <radical>sword</radical> and a <radical>knife</radical>. Now that you have them in there, you have to make them <kanji>separate</kanji> from each other.

Cut <radical>grain</radical>s with a <radical>knife</radical> to make them smaller and you'll make a great <kanji>profit</kanji>. By cutting them, now you can get three grains worth of money for what was once a single grain.

A <radical>woman</radical> sits on a <radical>stool</radical> to conserve her <radical>power</radical>, as her servants <kanji>toil</kanji> away in the kitchen. They toil away preparing a feast for this powerful woman while she kicks back on her cozy stool. She's a queen and deserves to be pampered.

A <radical>Viking</radical> in a position of <radical>power</radical> does not need to <kanji>labor</kanji> in the fields. Labor is for the weak! A Viking of power takes what he wants, and need not labor for it. A powerful Viking plunders all and takes what he wants!

<radical>Orders</radical> coming from your <radical>mouth</radical> will determine the <kanji>fate</kanji> of your soldiers. You are their commanding officer and your orders determine their <kanji>life</kanji> and death.

The <radical>mountain</radical> on top of the <radical>cliff</radical> is <radical>dry</radical> from the <kanji>coast</kanji> below. Just from looking at the raging <kanji>shore</kanji> below, you'd think everything would be wet, it's splashing everywhere!
As the year starts moving in the <radical>direction</radical> of <radical>winter</radical>, the trees must <kanji>release</kanji> their leaves.

You've been playing <radical>blackjack</radical> in the <radical>sun</radical> since <kanji>long ago</kanji>. This is the longest game of blackjack you've ever played and it feels like ages since you started. You've been sitting out in the sun playing blackjack since long, long ago.
A <radical>tsunami</radical> hits your <radical>skin</radical> and creates smaller <kanji>wave</kanji>s. Those hit you too!

A <radical>tsunami</radical> <radical>master</radical> has the power to <kanji>pour</kanji> water wherever he pleases. Tsunami masters are masters over the most powerful water force in the universe, so it makes sense that they have the ability to pour water at will, wherever they please. Best not tick off the master, unless you want a tsunami poured on your head.
Give <radical>trash</radical> to the <radical>moon</radical> and it will <kanji>nurture</kanji> and <kanji>raise</kanji> that trash like it's its own little moon baby.

Your <radical>fingers</radical> always seem to <radical>suit</radical> the random things you <kanji>pick up</kanji> off the ground. An old thimble. A discarded onion ring. A dead worm you tie in a knot. Your incredible fingers suit them beautifully, almost as if they were jewelry, so of course you pick up all of them.
Try to use your <radical>fingers</radical> to <radical>spoon</radical> out some of the <radical>sun</radical> and you'll come back with just one <kanji>finger</kanji>.

This <radical>tsunami</radical> is ridden by a <radical>sheep</radical> in classic <kanji>Western style</kanji>. And by Western style I mean the sheep is dressed in a cowboy outfit and has put a saddle atop the tsunami wave to ride it. It's a tsunami rodeo and this crazy sheep is riding that tsunami wave in classic Western style.

This kanji also means <kanji>ocean</kanji>, because presumably the people from the West, with their Western style, came from across the ocean. You'll want to be familiar with both meanings for vocab later on.

Your <radical>spirit</radical> should feel <radical>humble</radical> before a <kanji>god</kanji>'s <kanji>spirit</kanji>. You never really feel humble in front of anyone else, but if you meet a god's spirit… Well, you should probably lower yourself appropriately. Gods have powerful spirits.
<radical>Grain</radical>s are <radical>few</radical>. Imagine the last few grains trickling down the hourglass. You only have a <kanji>second</kanji> left.

There are pieces of <radical>thread</radical> on each <radical>escalator</radical> showing you what <kanji>level</kanji> they go to in your school. Each escalator takes you to a different <kanji>grade</kanji>, so make sure you follow the right thread or you'll end up in a class that's either way above or way below your level.

On a <radical>scooter</radical> there is a <radical>bear</radical> with a <radical>drop</radical> on its head trying to <kanji>follow</kanji> and <kanji>chase</kanji> you! You accidentally splashed it with water and it's not happy about it. You're on your own scooter, luckily, but that doesn't make this any less terrifying.
A <radical>simple</radical> <radical>drunkard</radical> starting a <kanji>war</kanji>.

<radical>Stand</radical> on your <radical>older brother</radical>. Now <radical>stand</radical> on your <radical>older brother</radical> again. You wish to stand on, and above, your older brother. You <kanji>compete</kanji> over and over again, to stand atop your older brother.

A <radical>drop</radical> of water to a <radical>root</radical> is <kanji>good</kanji>. It's good for the roots to grow and live and thrive. And what's good for roots is good for our plants and us humans too.
Using your <radical>construction</radical> <radical>power</radical> you build something great. A true <kanji>achievement</kanji> built for the achievement of making kanji learning easier!
This <radical>cow</radical> <radical>temple</radical> is <kanji>special</kanji>. This cow must have been very important to have an entire temple dedicated to it.

A <radical>leader</radical> stands upon the <radical>ground</radical> of the <radical>rice paddy</radical>. She is searching for <radical>treasure</radical>. It is said that this treasure here in this rice field will make things much easier for the leader (that's what leaders really want, after all). If she gets this treasure, it will be a great <kanji>convenience</kanji> for her, because convenience is everything when you're the leader.

Your <radical>leader</radical> makes you lift <radical>heavy</radical> loads with all your <radical>power</radical>, since this is what you do for <kanji>work</kanji>. Why do you this kind of work? Well, you're good at it and the leader makes you do it, I guess.
If you know the radical meaning <radical>orders</radical> you know the kanji meaning <kanji>orders</kanji> as well!

The <radical>sound</radical> of your <radical>heart</radical> gives me an <kanji>idea</kanji>. The methodic thump thump thumping of a heart puts me in a trance that gives me great ideas. It’s a very inspirational sound, the sound of a heart is. It gives me an idea. 

Alternatively, you could look at this kanji and see a "stand" radical and something that kind of (almost) looks like the kanji for "think." When you stand up and think, you come up with your very own <kanji>idea</kanji>s!

In your <radical>mouth</radical> there is a <radical>jet</radical> dropping <kanji>flavor</kanji> bombs. Every time you <kanji>taste</kanji> something, it's actually because a tiny jet has flown into your mouth to bomb you with flavor.
Who will <radical>say</radical> <radical>turkey</radical>? Who? <kanji>WHO</kanji>???
